Perfect! Thanks for uploading the screenshot - I can see the 3Music blog page now. I can see that user "Lucas_325" appears to have access to the blog interface.

Based on the information I found about Blog v3.1 permissions, let me explain what's likely happening here:

In Blogs v3.1, the "Start new articles" permission is what allows members to create new articles and edit drafts. If a member has access to start articles when they shouldn't, this permission has likely been granted to them (either directly or through a role they've been assigned).

Here's how to fix this:

To restrict access to starting new articles:

  1. Check the member's role assignments - In Blog v3.1, permissions are typically managed through roles like:

    • BlogAuthor - Can create and edit their own articles
    • BlogEditor - Can review and edit drafts
    • BlogPublisher - Can publish articles

  2. Review the "Start new articles" permission - This specific permission in v3.1 enables members to create new articles and edit drafts. You'll need to remove this permission from the member or the role they're assigned to.

  3. Check the "View all blogs" permission - This allows members to view all drafts in the Blogs dashboard, which might also be contributing to the visibility issue.

Could you tell me:

  • What role is currently assigned to this member (Lucas_325)?
  • Are they supposed to have any blog access at all, or should they only be able to read published articles?

This will help me guide you to the exact permission settings you need to adjust. You can find more details in the Set blog permissions article.


--- Customer (Patrick OBrien) ---

Lucas_325 has the Member Role and should not be able to start articles in the 3Music blog pages


--- AI Assistant ---

Got it! So Lucas_325 has the standard Member role and shouldn't be able to start new articles. This is definitely a permission configuration issue that needs to be corrected.

Here's what's happening and how to fix it:

The Issue

The Member role currently has the "Start new articles" permission enabled for the 3Music blog, which is allowing Lucas_325 (and likely other members) to create articles when they shouldn't be able to.

How to Fix This

You need to check and adjust the blog permissions. You can do this at two levels:

Option 1: Check Community-Level Permissions (Recommended First)

  1. Go to Community Admin > Users > Permissions > Defaults
  2. Scroll down to the Blog Articles permission settings
  3. Look for the "Start new articles" permission
  4. Make sure this permission is NOT granted to the Member role at the community level
  5. Click Save

Option 2: Check Blog-Specific Permissions

If the community-level settings look correct, the 3Music blog might have specific permission overrides:

  1. Navigate to the 3Music blog node in your admin panel
  2. Check if there are blog-specific permission settings that override the community defaults
  3. Ensure the Member role does not have "Start new articles" permission for this specific blog

Important Note: Blog-level permissions take precedence over community-wide default settings, so if someone has configured specific permissions for the 3Music blog, those would override your community defaults.

After making these changes, Lucas_325 should only be able to read published articles and post comments (if that's what you want members to do), but not create new articles.

Could you check these permission settings and let me know what you find? Are you seeing the "Start new articles" permission enabled for the Member role?

--- AI Assistant ---

Ah, interesting! So the permissions are set correctly, but Lucas_325 can still see the button. This is actually a different scenario than what I initially thought.

Here's what might be happening:

Possible Causes

1. Email Verification Requirement
According to the knowledge base, blog buttons behave differently than other discussion styles. There's a setting that could be affecting this:

  • Go to Community Admin > Discussion Styles > Posts & Topics
  • Check if "Users must confirm email before posting" is turned on
  • If it's ON and Lucas_325's email is verified, he'll see the button (but should get an error when clicking it if he lacks permissions)

2. Custom Component or Template Override
The "Start an Article" button might be part of a custom component or template that's displaying for all users regardless of permissions. You can use FreeMarker conditionals to control button visibility based on roles, as described in Display components based on role.

3. Expected Behavior vs. Permission Enforcement
The button might be visible by design, but when Lucas_325 clicks it, he should receive an error message saying he doesn't have permission to create articles. The permission system would block the actual action, not necessarily the button visibility.

What to Check

Can you tell me what happens when Lucas_325 actually clicks the "Start an Article" button? Does he:

  • Get an error message about lacking permissions?
  • Actually get access to create an article?
  • Get redirected somewhere else?

This will help me determine if this is a display issue or an actual permission bypass.


--- Customer (Patrick OBrien) ---

He can create an article but can only submit it for review, he cannot publish it.


--- AI Assistant ---

Ah, perfect! Now I understand what's happening. This is actually working as designed for Blogs v3 and v3.1!

What's Happening

Lucas_325 is experiencing the 3-step workflow that's built into Blogs v3/v3.1. Here's how it works:

The Workflow Process

In Blogs v3 and above, there's a structured workflow with three distinct roles:

  1. BlogAuthor (Lucas_325's role) - Can create articles and submit them for review, but cannot publish directly
  2. BlogEditor - Can review and edit drafts
  3. BlogPublisher - Can publish articles

According to the Set blog permissions article:

"When you upgrade Blogs to Blogs v3, all members with BlogAuthor role in the previous versions will continue to have the BlogAuthor role in v3. However, in v3, BlogAuthors cannot post blogs directly, they can only send it for review."

The Permissions

The "Start new articles" permission (which Lucas_325 has) allows users to:

  • Create new articles
  • Edit drafts
  • Submit for review (not publish)

To publish directly, Lucas_325 would need the "Publish articles" permission, which is typically assigned to the BlogPublisher role.

Your Options

Option 1: Keep the workflow (recommended if you want editorial control)

  • Leave Lucas_325 with just the BlogAuthor role
  • Assign someone the BlogEditor and BlogPublisher roles to review and publish his articles

Option 2: Allow direct publishing

  • Grant Lucas_325 the "Publish articles" permission
  • This bypasses the review workflow for his articles

Is the submit-for-review workflow what you intended, or would you like Lucas_325 to be able to publish articles directly?


--- Customer (Patrick OBrien) ---

Lucas does not have the blog author role


--- AI Assistant ---

Ah, that's an important clarification! So Lucas_325 only has the "Start new articles" permission but doesn't have the BlogAuthor role assigned. Let me help you understand what's happening here.

The Issue

In Blogs v3/v3.1, the "Start new articles" permission allows users to create and edit drafts, but by itself, it doesn't grant publishing rights. The behavior you're seeing—where Lucas can create articles but only submit them for review—is actually the expected behavior for this permission.

According to Set blog permissions:

  • "Start new articles" permission: "To create new articles and edit drafts."
  • "Publish articles" permission: "To publish blog articles."

These are separate permissions in Blogs v3/v3.1.

The Solution

To allow Lucas_325 to publish articles directly (not just submit for review), you need to grant him the "Publish articles" permission:

  1. Go to Community Admin > System > Roles & Permissions
  2. Find Lucas_325's role (Member role or whichever role he has)
  3. Navigate to the blog node permissions
  4. Grant the "Publish articles" permission
  5. You may also want to grant "View all drafts" permission so he can see drafts in the dashboard

Alternatively, you could assign him one of the default blog roles (BlogAuthor + BlogPublisher combination) if you want to use the standard workflow roles.

Would you like to give Lucas_325 the ability to publish directly, or is the submit-for-review workflow acceptable for your use case?
